resource.chars: Daumier is known for critically depicting the sociopolitical climate in France during the nineteenth century. Daumier empathized with Les Bons Bourgeois (the urban middle class). Daumier printed this lithograph in his Album du Siège, which depicts scenes of everyday life amidst the chaos of the Franco-Prussian war, the siege of Paris, and political satire aimed at the government and its leaders. France declared war on Prussia in July 1870, but was quickly defeated due to Prussia's superior military and tactics. The war had a devastating impact on French civilians, particularly those living in Paris, which was besieged for several months. Parisians' lives altered dramatically during the four month siege. During 23 nights of bombardement in January 1871, some 12,000 shells fell on Paris neighborhoods, killing about 400 people.
The lithograph portrays "The Bombardment," referencing the bombings of the Franco-Purssian War https://ehistory.osu.edu/articles/siege-paris-during-franco-prussian-war
The caption notes an exchange between a father and son, which translates to "What is that, dad?" The father replies, "It is the last of the fireworks of August 15."

However, the dialogue between the father and son reveals that these are not fireworks at all, but bombs falling on the city. The title's reference to a fireworks display on August 15th adds a layer of irony to the scene, remeniscent of Louis Napoleon’s decree of moving the national holiday from the original Bastille Day on July 14 to August 15, known as La Saint-Napoléon.
Daumier's use of irony in this lithograph offers a poignant critique of the disconnect between the ruling class and the suffering of ordinary people during wartime.
